sense.def: to appear in the place N, to become explicit in N
use for going (of roads) 出於王之塗
go out, leave the place one is in/home (for an errand)

entry.def: Chū 出 refers abstractly to the act of causing someone to leave a territory. [GENERAL], [MARGINAL]

Chū 出 (NB: rù 入cannot be used as an antonym for this meaning.) refers to something that pre-exists emerging or moving from an initial state of hiddenness or non-obviousness to a state of manifest visibility (in analogy with the basic meaning of the word "to come out"). [SPECIFIC]

sense.def: arise (from something or somebody); proceed (from something or somebody); take (something) as one's point of departure
cause to go out: give up and hand over, German: herausgeben
come to think of, think up, invent
remove the contextually determinate N1 from the N2

entry.def: The standard word for divorce refers only to the husband sending away his wife: chū 出.

sense.def: to send away; (for a mother-in-law) to send away (a daughter-in-law); to divorce (a woman)
(possible, conceivable) divorce, the (possibility of) having taken away one's status as a wife
cause to arise> give rise to, bring into existence
be in (like 在), see HDC meaning No. 27. German: sich befinden

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

sense.def: (of arrows etc) land outside of, hit outside of (the target)
cause N to get outside > bring out
come out of the contextually determinate place N
one exchange in the tradition of qingtan "pure conversation" consisting of a proposition and an objection to it

entry.def: Chū 出 (ant. rù 入 "income") refers specifically to monetary expenses, often in a somewhat theoretical context of "economics".

sense.def: excel N, be better than N
be fled from > be escaped from

entry.def: Chū 出 (ant. rù 入"remain inside") refers to the leaving of an enclosed space.

sense.def: depart, leave the place where one happens to be (to leave the room, leave the house; leave the capital); come out; set out on an expedition
go out on a military campaign
come out (from the mouth etc) see ISSUE
leave through, come out of (the door)
to go out in order to V
complement with verbs other than verbs of movements (V out)
direction verbal complement: V towards the outside; V out
go out in order to V
leave [one's home]> be in public service, not lead a merely private life
go out to V; come out to V
cause to go out, send out, send forth, give out (loans etc.)
cause to get out; bring out (an army into battle)
be sent out, get sent out
CHEMLA 2003: go out; cause to go out
be sent out; (of troops:) be brought out into battle
OBI: coming out> rising (as of sun)
cause N1 to come out from the opening N2
be given out; be sent out
promulgate; publish so as make into a legal order or command
CAUSE TO EMERGE> create, produce; undertake as an independent agent (a project of action)

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典
簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Chū 出 is a polite periphrastic term occasionally used for going into exile.

sense.def: leave the country; go into exile; be abroad, be on an outing; leave one's home; be away from home; be out and about
lead out, lead into the field (an army)

entry.def: The dominant word for being away from home or abroad is chū 出.

sense.def: abroad; outside the court; outside the home
abroadNB: This may be explained as a subordinate sentence "when X is/was abroad".
go abroad; spend one's time abroad
have as ancestor> descend from as ancestor, be descended from
put forward or advocate (a certain intellectual position); utter

entry.def: Chuì 出 (ant. liú 留 "keep in retention") is a colourless term referring to letting someone out of an enclosure, typically prison.
Chū 出 (ant. rù 入 "have as income") refers to the use of necessary resources in money in order to obtain something.

sense.def: pay out; hand out by way of payment; pay with
